Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Computational Social Science at the University of Notre Dame

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. As such, it has both scientific and societal benefits, and it integrates research and education. This award promotes the progress of social science discoveries through the application of advanced computational (computer) applications to solve problems of national interest such as personality analysis (psychology), interpersonal networks (sociology), family savings (economics) and digital introspection and archiving of architectural landmarks (anthropology). Broader impacts will include the critical advancement of education in computational social science as identified in the Presidential Information Technology Advisory Committee report and development of the nation's future social scientists. The program's engagement of under-represented groups and the opportunities for interaction with high school students and international research peers will have a broad impact in their professional STEM development.

This award establishes an REU Site at the Center for Research Computing (CRC) at the University of Notre Dame; an ideal setting for the REU student to become familiar with interdisciplinary computational social science research. The CRC provides access to research groups working across a diverse range of social science problems including (a) Multivariate Data Mining for the Analysis of Personality, (b) Explorations on the Effects of Pervasive Networking on Social Relationships, (c) Developing Large Overlapping Generations Models of Household Savings, and (d) Digital Anthropological and Archaeological Data Capture, Archive, and Analysis. The social science students learn how to use the most current cyberinfrastructure tools and receive training on fundamental scientific computing skills and techniques. The program involves 10 students every summer, and each student spends 10 weeks at the University of Notre Dame. Intellectual merit of the project is grounded in four core areas of expertise: computational psychology, computational sociology, computational economics, and cyberinfrastructure development for the social sciences. The program gives students and faculty participants a chance to carry out collaborative, interdisciplinary research in the computational sciences. Students become part of an interdisciplinary team and experience the rewards of scientific collaboration. For faculty, the REU program offers an opportunity to explore novel research areas and form new collaborations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research: Each summer the REU participants were required to present their research findings publicly via a campus wide undergraduate research poster symposium and 3-5 minute research summary videos developed for non-expert public consumption and posted openly on YouTube. All of the research posters, videos and supplemental content are also publicly available on the ND CRC website REU pages (https://crc.nd.edu/outreach/reu-program). The public presentation provides peer accountability for both the student and mentor to be as effcient as possible during the short 10 week session.

Highlight Events: In addition to the standard training and research regime our team made every effort to enhance the student learning through opportunistic participation in conferences and workshops in the greater midwest. We were very fortunate that the new International Conference in Computational Social Science (IC2S2) was held at Northwestern in the summers of 2016 and 2018. All students were registered and transported to the conference both years providing many of them with their first academic conference experience.

The students also had the opportunity to tour the Union Station Technology Center co-location data center facility and see the computational infrastructure behind their scientic inquiry, first hand. Computer systems engineers and administrators were on hand to provide expert descriptions of the technical components and students were provided with a view into the complex computer architecture that serves as both computational capacity and sometimes bottleneck of scientic workows.

Training: The ND CRC is fortunate to have a large staff of computational research faculty and engineers who are excited to share their expertise with the REU participants each summer. With some modications in course length and content to better meet student and mentor requirements as outlined in end of year survey results we established the following core training regimen specific to CSS. Additional training opportunities such as poster preparation, GRE study skills and weekly professional development luncheons were also available in concert with peer REU programs offered at Notre Dame.

CSS Core Technical Training: Introduction to HPC (2 hours), Linux Training (2 hours), Computer Architecture (2 hours), Computational Workows (2 hours), Hadoop/Spark/Big Data (1 hour), R Training (3 hours), Stata Training (2 hours), Software Engineering Best Practices (2 hours) Deep Learning (2 hours), Python Programming (4 hours), 5 Minute Research Elevator Pitch (1 hour).
